awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  A Geospatial Analysis of Alpine Glacial Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
This doctoral dissertation research improvement project will use geospatial analysis to evaluate the extent of changes in remote alpine glaciers from the early 20th century to the present.  The analysis will use satellite images and an archive of recently recovered air-photos from historical expeditions.  Findings from the study will contribute to the limited knowledge of alpine glacier histories in remote regions, with implications for future estimates of ice loss and global sea-level change. The research will capitalize on a unique collection of historical air-photos, which have been underutilized as a source of data, thereby providing an opportunity to assess alpine glacier change on a regional scale.  This study will foster a new international collaboration with the Natural History Museum of Denmark and engage undergraduate students in polar geospatial research.  The doctoral student and her advisor will develop workshops for K-12 STEM teachers from the Chicago public-school district.  As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Most previous studies of remote glaciers have been restricted to the satellite era of the late 20th and early 21st centuries. Thus, the long-term, Holocene, history of these glaciers and ice caps is generally not well known, despite their importance to global sea level. Of particular relevance to the future, their sensitivity to sustained periods of past warming is poorly understood. To facilitate improved estimates of past glacier activity as well as future glacier change, the doctoral student will utilize historical air-photos, Landsat and Worldview satellite data, as well as several open-sourced digital analytical tools to reconstruct historical glacier extent and area, and model glacier Equilibrium Line Altitude (ELA).  In combination with the related research which reconstructs long-term Holocene glacier histories using lake sediments in the same region, this complementary geospatial analysis will place 20th and 21th century glacier variability into a longer-term perspective. Although this research project will focus on alpine glaciers in South Greenland, it is highly relevant to understanding the impacts of global environmental change more broadly.  The study aims to develop improved approaches for the historical analysis of glacial change, which will be useful for natural resource management in many other locations, including within the United States.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The retreat of glaciers and ice caps worldwide has accelerated in recent decades. Their continued melt has contributed significantly to the observed sea–level rise, including along United States coastlines, and is expected to alter local hydrological systems, affecting freshwater availability and quality. Despite these challenging impacts, little is known about glacier and ice cap variations prior to the satellite era—a limitation that hinders our longer–term understanding of their response to changes in climate. 

The lack of multi–decadal observational records is especially apparent in the Arctic—a region that is warming much faster than the global average. This research investigated how South Greenland’s mountain glaciers have changed in length since the end of the Little Ice Age, a cold period between ~1250 and 1900 CE when most glaciers across Greenland reached their historical maximum extents. We mapped changes in the position of ~60 glacier fronts over the past ~120 years using a rare archive of historical aerial photographs along with modern satellite imagery. To capture the state of glaciers in the mid–20th century, roughly seven–hundred historical air photos were scanned and digitized from paper copies. To extend our record to the beginning of the 20th century, the positions of moraines and trimlines—visible evidence that mark the glacier’s historical maximum extent, were mapped. In addition, recently developed geospatial tools were used to model past glacier characteristics for an additional ~40 glaciers to investigate how cool the Little Ice Age was in South Greenland. The final phase of this project is further investigating regional differences in glacier length change within Greenland by comparison with other comparable studies, and analysis of climatological and glaciological data. This work will improve understanding of the mechanisms driving these regional differences. 

By extending the limited time frame of observational records from South Greenland—an understudied area with abundant outlying glaciers, this project placed recent glacier retreat into a century–long perspective, which will ultimately help to improve understanding of glacier sensitivity to atmospheric climate variability in this distinctive region. This work has also demonstrated a novel workflow and the potential for reconstruction of a large number of glaciers to infer past climatic information. Although this research has focused on mountain glaciers in South Greenland, it is highly relevant to understanding the impacts of global environmental change more broadly. The research developed improved approaches for analysis of glacial change, which will be useful for natural resource management in many other locations, including within the United States.

One Northwestern Ph.D. student and one Northwestern undergraduate Earth Science major participated in this research. The project provided graduate student Larocca with additional experience in developing skills in geographic information science, coding, and other computing skills, as well as experience in mentorship and advisement of an undergraduate honors thesis. The work has also contributed to the development of a longer–term research program on Arctic glacier change for Larocca. The undergraduate student, who has graduated at the time of this report, has entered a graduate program in glaciology. This project also fostered a new international collaboration with researchers at the University of Copenhagen in Denmark, where the original historical air photos are housed.

Larocca has shared results with colleagues at geospatial and Arctic–focused workshops and conferences. Three conference presentations, one workshop presentation, one undergraduate honors thesis, and one chapter of Larocca’s dissertation resulted from this research at the time this report was filed. Two journal articles are in preparation and will be submitted for peer–review. The project has engaged K–12 students and broad audiences in polar geospatial research through presentations to Earth science and journalism classes at Northwestern, through Northwestern outreach programs for high school teachers and students, and through participation in several Chicago and New York Public School events.
